document_title: Brachypodium distachyon Seedlings Display Accession-Specific Morphological and Transcriptomic Responses to the Microgravity Environment of the International Space Station
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of microgravity on Brachypodium distachyon seedlings, a monocot model plant, grown on the International Space Station (ISS). Three accessions (Bd21, Bd21-3, and Gaz8) were compared to ground controls. Microgravity exposure resulted in shorter roots and longer root hairs across all accessions. Shoot growth was also reduced in the Bd21 accession under microgravity, while Bd21-3 and Gaz8 showed similar shoot growth rates. Transcriptomic analysis revealed significant accession-specific responses to microgravity, with Gaz8 exhibiting the largest number of differentially expressed genes (DEGs), followed by Bd21 and Bd21-3. Common DEGs between accessions were enriched for photosynthesis-related genes, which were down-regulated in shoots. Oxidative stress response genes were differentially regulated in shoots and roots, suggesting distinct adaptation strategies. The study also identified potential roles for retrograde signaling and PIF genes in mediating shoot responses to microgravity, and highlighted accession-specific differences in transcriptional and post-translational regulation pathways. Overall, Brachypodium seedlings exhibit complex, accession- and organ-specific responses to microgravity, with implications for developing crops for space exploration.
key_findings: Brachypodium distachyon roots grew slower and displayed longer root hairs under microgravity compared to ground controls across all three accessions.
Shoot growth was reduced in the Bd21 accession under microgravity, but not in Bd21-3 and Gaz8.
Transcriptomic responses to microgravity were highly accession-specific, with Gaz8 showing the most DEGs, followed by Bd21 and Bd21-3.
Down-regulation of photosynthesis-related genes was observed in the shoots of microgravity-exposed seedlings, potentially linked to oxidative stress and retrograde signaling.
Distinct biological strategies involving oxidative stress response, wall remodeling, and hormonal signaling were employed by roots and shoots to adapt to microgravity.
The study identified potential regulatory pathways involving PIF genes and phytochrome A in mediating microgravity responses in shoots.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific molecular mechanisms behind accession- and organ-specific responses to microgravity.
Evaluating the role of retrograde signaling and PIF genes in plant adaptation to spaceflight.
Exploring the connection between gravity, photosynthesis, and cell wall restructuring in plants.
Developing improved crop cultivars and cultivation methodologies for bioregenerative life support systems in space.
Conducting similar studies on cultivated crop species to assess their adaptability to spaceflight.

conclusions: Brachypodium distachyon seedlings exhibit accession- and organ-specific morphological and transcriptomic responses to microgravity, involving oxidative stress, wall remodeling, and photosynthesis regulation. While some responses are common with other plant species like Arabidopsis, significant variations exist between accessions, highlighting the need for direct evaluation of candidate crop responses for space agriculture.
impact_statement: This study provides crucial insights into monocot plant adaptation to microgravity, informing the development of crops for sustainable life support systems in future space exploration missions.
